title: August 12, 2025: Arizona Board of Regents Takes Action Amid Drought Concerns
bodyText:
As concerns about Arizona's water future grow, the Arizona Board of Regents (ABOR) and the state's public universities are collaborating to safeguard groundwater resources. On 12th December 2025, it was announced that a Regents' Grant is funding the Arizona Tri-University Recharge and Water Reliability Project, aimed at addressing the pressing issue of water scarcity in the region.

Kathy Jacobs, a professor of environmental science at the University of Arizona and director of the Center for Climate Adaptation Science and Solutions, highlighted the urgency of the situation. The Arizona Department of Water Resources has tasked the project team with developing methods to capture precipitation and runoff before it evaporates, thereby replenishing the state's aquifers. "The reason that's a big issue is that more than 95% of the water that falls on the ground either as snow or rain in Arizona evaporates back into the atmosphere," Jacobs stated. She emphasized that capturing even a small percentage of this water could significantly benefit rural areas.

Groundwater currently accounts for approximately 40% of Arizona's water supply, yet its monitoring remains intricate, particularly in sparsely populated regions. According to Jacobs, the project employs some of the most advanced modeling techniques available in the state and potentially the United States. "We're using machine learning and the national water model, along with locally adjusted models that examine the entire hydrologic cycle in great detail," she explained. This innovative approach allows for the generation of new insights into the water cycle across every watershed in Arizona, a level of detail not previously accessible.

The Arizona Board of Regents underscored the importance of this initiative in a press release, describing it as a scientific foundation for water reliability amid prolonged drought conditions and declining allocations from the Colorado River. The landscapes across the state are experiencing unprecedented stress, characterized by low soil moisture, drought-affected vegetation, and increased fire danger. This collaborative effort aims to address these critical challenges and ensure sustainable water management for future generations.

As Arizona grapples with the realities of climate change and water scarcity, the proactive measures being taken by the Arizona Board of Regents and its partner universities are vital. The success of the Tri-University Recharge and Water Reliability Project may serve as a model for other regions facing similar environmental challenges, demonstrating the importance of innovation and collaboration in safeguarding natural resources.

title: August 12, 2025: Arizona Board of Regents Takes Action Amid Drought Concerns
bodyText:
As concerns about Arizona's water future grow, the Arizona Board of Regents (ABOR) and the state's public universities are collaborating to safeguard groundwater resources. On 12th December 2025, it was announced that a Regents' Grant is funding the Arizona Tri-University Recharge and Water Reliability Project, aimed at addressing the pressing issue of water scarcity in the region.

Kathy Jacobs, a professor of environmental science at the University of Arizona and director of the Center for Climate Adaptation Science and Solutions, highlighted the urgency of the situation. The Arizona Department of Water Resources has tasked the project team with developing methods to capture precipitation and runoff before it evaporates, thereby replenishing the state's aquifers. "The reason that's a big issue is that more than 95% of the water that falls on the ground either as snow or rain in Arizona evaporates back into the atmosphere," Jacobs stated. She emphasized that capturing even a small percentage of this water could significantly benefit rural areas.

Groundwater currently accounts for approximately 40% of Arizona's water supply, yet its monitoring remains intricate, particularly in sparsely populated regions. According to Jacobs, the project employs some of the most advanced modeling techniques available in the state and potentially the United States. "We're using machine learning and the national water model, along with locally adjusted models that examine the entire hydrologic cycle in great detail," she explained. This innovative approach allows for the generation of new insights into the water cycle across every watershed in Arizona, a level of detail not previously accessible.

The Arizona Board of Regents underscored the importance of this initiative in a press release, describing it as a scientific foundation for water reliability amid prolonged drought conditions and declining allocations from the Colorado River. The landscapes across the state are experiencing unprecedented stress, characterized by low soil moisture, drought-affected vegetation, and increased fire danger. This collaborative effort aims to address these critical challenges and ensure sustainable water management for future generations.

As Arizona grapples with the realities of climate change and water scarcity, the proactive measures being taken by the Arizona Board of Regents and its partner universities are vital. The success of the Tri-University Recharge and Water Reliability Project may serve as a model for other regions facing similar environmental challenges, demonstrating the importance of innovation and collaboration in safeguarding natural resources.

title: Tuvalu citizens keen to flee rising waters
bodyText:
More than half of the citizens of Tuvalu have applied for a visa to permanently migrate to Australia.

Just more than a month ago, Australia opened The Falepili Mobility Pathway ballot, a program to provide citizens of the tiny island nation of Tuvalu a permanent migration pathway.

The country has a population of 10,643, 5157 of whom entered the lottery. This was through 1466 registrations, with many of the people being included as family members on applications.

The ballot, which closed on Friday, randomly selects up to 280 people each year to apply for the visa.

It is open to all Tuvalu citizens, and visa holders do not need to gain employment in Australia before applying.

Selections for the ballot will take place between July 25, 2025 and January 25, 2026.

The scheme allows successful applicants to live, work and study anywhere in Australia indefinitely, sponsor relatives to also migrate and apply for citizenship once eligible.

The island nation is particularly exposed to the effects of climate change, with this program providing a path to flee as the impacts worsen.

The pathway is part of the Australia-Tuvalu Falepili Union that both countries signed on August 28, 2024.

Also included in the union is a commitment of $38m to invest in climate adaptation measures on the island. When the ballot opened last month, Pacific Island Affairs Minister Pat Conroy called it the "most significant agreement" between Australia and a Pacific country since PNG's independence in 1975.

title: August 16, 2025: UNM's ARID Institute Secures $7 Million Grant for Watershed Management Innovation
bodyText:
The University of New Mexico's Accelerating Resilience Innovations in Drylands (ARID) Institute has received a significant boost in funding to enhance watershed management across the state. A four-year, $7 million grant from the National Science Foundation (NSF) through the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) program was awarded on 16th August 2025. This funding aims to establish a comprehensive network that will unite researchers, land managers, and communities in New Mexico, focusing on sustainable forest and watershed management.

New Mexico's forested watersheds are vital for water supply, carbon storage, and cultural significance, yet they are increasingly threatened by climate change, wildfires, and competing land uses. The most affected areas include the Rio Grande and Pecos River Basins, which primarily serve Indigenous and rural communities reliant on surface water for agriculture and daily life. The combined effects of diminishing snowpack, fluctuating precipitation patterns, and intensified wildfire activity present significant challenges for watershed management, making this initiative timely and necessary.

The NSF EPSCoR Research Incubators for STEM Excellence (E-RISE-RII) project, titled 'Forest Research for New Mexico Water and Carbon Management' (FOR-NM), intends to integrate expertise from various fields. By combining knowledge in ecology, hydrology, remote sensing, and machine learning with social sciences, the project aims to provide actionable insights into watershed management. Lead Principal Investigator Marcy Litvak, a UNM Biology Professor, emphasized the project's dual focus on gathering critical ecological data and fostering economic and workforce development through community engagement.

FOR-NM will target New Mexico's Top 500 priority watersheds and will utilize advanced technologies such as high-resolution satellite data and machine learning models to evaluate forest management impacts. The initiative will monitor two watersheds intensively, including the Santa Fe Watershed, to examine how management practices influence hydrologic connectivity and ecological outcomes. This research will also pilot a Guided Transformation framework that merges scientific findings with community needs, aiming to deliver practical climate-adaptation solutions.

The ARID Institute at the University of New Mexico is poised to set a precedent in forest, water, and carbon management not only within the state but also as a model for similar ecosystems in the Southwestern United States and globally. The collaboration includes partners such as New Mexico State University and the Asombro Institute for Science Education, highlighting the initiative's comprehensive approach to addressing the urgent challenges posed by climate change.

title: WEEKLY RECAP: QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK AUG 20, 2025
bodyText:
+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY [4 Press Releases]

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY SECURES $5.8 MILLION FOR HEALTH RESEARCH INITIATIVES

Queen's University has been awarded a total of $5.8 million in funding from the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (CIHR) for six research projects that aim to enhance patient care, promote health equity, and foster innovative therapies. The funding comprises five Project Grants, which support research led by investigators in various health domains, along with one Priority Announcement award. The Priority Announcements fund initiatives that are in line with certain national research objectives set by CIHR, such as bolstering primary care or expanding access to preventive health services. Out of a competitive field of 2,814 applications across the country, these six projects from Queen's were selected as part of only 435 that received CIHR funding.

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY RESEARCHERS BRIDGE SCIENCE AND POLICY

In Ontario's legislature, researchers are discovering innovative ways to influence public policy. This spring, Dr. Ryan Grant from Electrical and Computer Engineering and Dr. Yanwen Zhang from Mechanical and Materials Engineering represented Queen's University at the first-ever Science Meets Parliament Ontario. This initiative aims to connect scientists with provincial lawmakers to enhance the integration of research into policymaking. Organized by the Canadian Science Policy Centre, the program allows academic researchers to interact with Members of Provincial Parliament (MPPs) and legislative staff, participate in question period, and engage in workshops focused on science communication and public involvement. For Drs. Grant and Zhang, this was a chance to link their research efforts to pressing issues on Ontario's policy agenda.

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY HOSTS EDVARD MUNCH EXHIBITION DELVING INTO THEMES OF ILLNESS AND CARE

Norwegian artist Edvard Munch, celebrated for his iconic painting The Scream, dedicated his career to examining the emotional and physical challenges faced by the human body. A new exhibition titled Lifeblood at the MUNCH museum in Oslo connects his artworks with historical medical artifacts, reflecting on his personal experiences with illness and care. It also aims to address the complexities of health and sickness, as well as the cycles of birth and death, highlighting the dynamics of giving and receiving care. Curated by Allison Morehead, a professor at Queen's University, this exhibition is the result of extensive research in both art history and the medical humanities. It opened its doors on June 27, 2025, and is projected to attract over 250,000 visitors before concluding on September 21, 2025.

+ QUEEN'S UNIVERSITY PIONEERS INNOVATIVE APPROACHES TO SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE

If you've ever looked up at the Queen's Biosciences Complex and wondered about the greenhouse perched on its roof, you're not alone. This plant haven is part of the Queen's University Phytotron - a state-of-the-art research facility dedicated to advanced plant science research and operated by the Department of Biology. The Phytotron features six climate-controlled greenhouse zones, 30 environmental growth chambers, and a lab. Each area is designed to replicate a vast array of environmental conditions, including temperature, humidity, CO levels, air flow, and light quality. The facility's conservatory boasts more than 150 tropical plant species that facilitate research across various fields, including plant biology, agriculture, climate adaptation, and global food security.

title: New Roadmap to help guide sustainable growth of Queensland’s intensive animal industries: QFF
bodyText:
Queensland Farmers’ Federation (QFF), Media Release, 19 August 2025

Queensland’s intensive animal industries have released a 10-year roadmap that sets a clear and collaborative pathway for future growth, resilience, and sustainability across the sector, while supporting food security for Queenslanders and Australia.

Link to Image

The Intensive Animal Industries Queensland Roadmap 2025–2035outlines a strategic, industry-led plan for managing the challenges and opportunities facing Queensland’s pork, poultry (eggs and chicken meat), dairy and feedlot sectors.

Together, these industries collectively contribute close to $1.75 billion annually to the state economy and provide more than 50 per cent of Queenslanders’ daily protein intake.

The roadmap was developed through extensive consultation between industry leaders, government, researchers and peak bodies, including the Queensland Farmers’ Federation (QFF), and with funding support from the Queensland Government.

The roadmap identifies four key focus areas for the decade ahead: Land Use Planning and Management, Animal Health, Welfare and Biosecurity, Market Demand and Supply, and Value-Based Food Production.

QFF CEO Jo Sheppard said the roadmap reflects the importance of planning now to secure future food production and food security in Queensland and nationally.

“The intensive animals industries are incredibly important for food security and the supply of protein to Queensland, Australian and global consumers.”

“This roadmap is an example of Queensland’s intensive animal industries working together collectively to find solutions to the shared challenges facing their sector, and proactively identifying a unified pathway forward,” Ms Sheppard said.

“With the global population expected to reach nearly 10 billion by 2050, the pressure to produce more protein sustainably is growing. These industries are amongst the most innovative and agile in the world but face complex issues ranging from land use and emissions reduction to biosecurity and market demand.

“This document is both a strategic foundation and a living plan that will evolve as the sector navigates change, builds resilience, and strives for value-based, sustainable and profitable growth.”

Department of Primary Industries Deputy Director-General Ash Bacon said the roadmap supports Primary Industries Prosper 2050 – the Queensland Government’s 25-year blueprint co-designed with industry to shape a thriving future for Queensland and our primary industries. 

“Queensland’s intensive animal industries are essential to our state’s food security and economic success, particularly in regional areas,” said Mr Bacon.

“This roadmap ensures government and industry remain aligned in navigating challenges like climate adaptation, land and water use competition, and sustainable production. We’re proud to have supported this initiative and look forward to ongoing collaboration.”

The roadmap process brought together industry leaders who recognised shared challenges and the need for coordinated action. A series of workshops helped shape the roadmap’s key pillars, ensuring broad representation from across industry, academia, and government.

The roadmap is also a timely contribution to the broader discussion around the role of agriculture in securing Australia’s food future, particularly as environmental targets, shifting consumer expectations, and global supply chain pressures reshape the operating landscape.

“Planning for the future of food requires a long-term vision,” Ms Sheppard said.

“This roadmap gives us that and puts industry at the heart of the solution.”

title: Making sustainability easy for SMEs
bodyText:
For many small and medium enterprises, adopting sustainable business practices can be another load on their already busy business life.

EcoBiz, a sustainability program delivered by Business Chamber Queensland, aims to arm SMEs with the sustainability tools to not simply survive in an ever-changing landscape, but thrive.

"We've been around for 157 years; we know business," says Business Chamber Queensland chief executive Heidi Cooper. "We've taken our deep understanding of business to develop a sustainability program that is designed by business for business and gets real business outcomes.

"The most rewarding thing with the whole ecoBiz program is when you hear people say, 'I didn't know I could do these things. I didn't know what was possible.' And we see businesses go from strength to strength."

Delivered in partnership with the Queensland government, ecoBiz has been helping businesses adopt sustainable practices for the past decade.

Free to participants with fewer than 200 full-time equivalent staff, it has helped Queensland businesses avoid more than $3.15 million in energy, water and waste costs in 2023-24, and 12,077 tonnes of carbon emissions.

"Unfortunately, natural disasters have become a part of business life in Queensland," Cooper says. "That's why we have developed a Climate Adaptation module to help businesses be more resilient and establish business continuity practices ahead of the impacts of a natural disaster and climate shocks."

The June launch of the Climate Adaptation module adds another vital layer to a sophisticated program that meets businesses where they are at in their sustainability journey, and opens their eyes to the myriad opportunities that engaging in this space present.

"We've seen some of the most challenging operating environments in decades," Cooper says. "Businesses need a direct outcome, a saving around their energy, waste and water costs, and practical measures to support their business, alongside future-focused measures like supply chain, procurement and export readiness.

"But what we're also working on is: How do they get a compounding impact? How do they enable their employees to think differently? How do they see that behavioural change? How do they increase productivity? How do they think differently about innovation and a circular economy?"

Engaging with ecoBiz to help future-proof your business is simple. A five-minute online quiz indicates your business's sustainability maturity level - ranging from emerging, to developing, accelerating or maturing. Relevant articles and videos help build knowledge that is tailored to your needs, then the assessment tool identifies specific challenges and opportunities.

An action plan maps out steps to be taken in time frames that are stipulated by the business, and an implementation dashboard tracks progress as the steps are put in place, all with ecoBiz's support.

For Cooper, the most rewarding feedback is from business owners who aren't just being directed to a website and expected to work it out for themselves. They like that ecoBiz's programs are curated specifically for them, by people with SME experience who understand their challenges - and the opportunities they can present.

"This isn't a cookie-cutter, it's designed for their business," Cooper says. "We know businesses have more than enough on their plate, so we do that hard work for them so the program meets them where they're at, and builds their maturity the whole way through."

Olenka Muzik is publican of the Euramo Hotel, inland from Mission Beach and widely known as The Yacht Club because locals head there in their tinnies when the Tully River floods. The pub is on higher ground, and acts as a vital community gathering place when disaster strikes.

"I'm lucky that I've always made sure I've got enough stock to last me a couple of weeks if something goes wrong," Muzik says.

With the road between Townsville and Cairns cut off for 18 days already this year, exploring supply chain opportunities is becoming increasingly vital.

Muzik was googling ways of saving on power bills when she found ecoBiz, and was keen to discover how it might help future-proof the pub.

Through the ecoBiz program, the Euramo Hotel has already saved on its energy, waste and water and implemented practical steps to establish more sustainable practices.

Now the business is keen to be a part of the newly released Climate Adaptation module so it can look at ways to better prepare for natural disasters and put in place long-term business continuity practices.

EcoBiz program manager Catie Simmons says the Euramo Hotel offers a great example of the bespoke and interactive nature of the climate risk assessment tool. Muzik can simply click on her area of Far North Queensland to access the latest climate projection data showing likely changes in the region.

"We want to leave businesses with something that can help them prepare for future changes," Simmons says. "We want them to feel empowered."

Cooper encourages SMEs to take the time during "normal" operation to prepare themselves and their staff for the changing climate ahead.

"We're super-excited to be launching the Climate Adaptation module," she says. "It has never been more important for Queensland businesses to prepare for potential natural disasters, and we are so proud to be able to support them to manage through what can be some of the most challenging times."

title: Rollerskate coach gets a Greens light
bodyText:
Ellyane Wall has been endorsed by the Northern Territory Greens as part of her bid to run as a councillor for the City of Darwin's Chan Ward.

It marks the first public endorsement from any political party in the City of Darwin thus far in the 2025 election campaign.

In a statement, the NT Greens said Ms Wall was "passionate about climate action, accessibility and inclusion, participatory democracy, and youth representation".

Ms Wall volunteers with Rapid Creek Landcare and Birdlife NT, and she works as a rollerskating coach.

Chan Ward comprises the suburbs of Coconut Grove, East Point, Fannie Bay, Jingili, Ludmilla, Millner, Nightcliff and Rapid Creek.

Current councillor Morgan Rickard, who represents Chan Ward, was backed by the NT Greens in the 2021 local government elections, which he won in.

More recently, NT Greens candidate Kat McNamara narrowly won the electorate of Nightcliff in the 2024 NT Election.

Ms Wall said in a statement that Darwin was "my favourite place on Earth". "I'm running for council because I want to make sure that my generation feels that they can build their futures here," she said.

"I love our community, our town, and our unique way of life. Serving on council is an opportunity for me to give back to the community that has so fundamentally shaped who I am today.

"Council is so much more than rates, roads and rubbish. Our councils make decisions that impact everyone's experience of our community for years to come.

"I will be a strong voice for young people in our city, who are currently so under represented on council.

title: August 19, 2025: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation Commits $2.5 Billion to Women's Health
bodyText:
In a landmark announcement, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will invest $2.5 billion in women's health over the next five years. This commitment, revealed on August 4th, 2025, marks one of the organization's largest financial pledges to date, aimed at addressing long-overlooked health conditions affecting women worldwide.

Bill Gates emphasized the urgency of this investment, stating, "Too many health conditions that affect women, including preeclampsia, endometriosis, and menopause, have been overlooked for far too long." He further noted that enhancing women's health can lead to improved family health, stronger economies, and a more equitable society. Gates expressed concern that women's health remains underfunded and sidelined, with too many preventable deaths occurring.

The funding will target five key areas, with the foundation aiming to boost research, develop innovative products, and ensure they are accessible globally. Dr. Anita Zaidi, who leads gender equality efforts at the Gates Foundation, highlighted the dire need for focused research in women's health. "For too long, women have suffered from health conditions that are misunderstood, misdiagnosed, or ignored," she stated in the news release. This investment seeks to ignite a new era of innovation prioritizing women's health in research and development.

Zaidi also pointed to a startling statistic regarding the lack of research on women's health, revealing that only a handful of women have been studied in significant health-related research. While the $2.5 billion investment is substantial, she described it as "a drop in the bucket," urging other philanthropists, governments, and private entities to join in the effort to close the funding gap in women's health.

The announcement comes as Bill Gates continues his philanthropic journey, with plans to donate his entire $200 billion fortune by 2045. Meanwhile, Melinda French Gates, who departed from the foundation last year, has been pursuing her initiatives focused on women's health, further amplifying the importance of this sector. As the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation takes this bold step, the call for broader support in women's health innovation remains paramount.

title: Wariness over private water and property policies that impact landholders
bodyText:
Advocate calls on ag sector not to take water rights for granted.

Water is the forgotten resource.

But there are a range of threats and opportunities when it comes to private water and property rights.

Western Australian Water Users Coalition (WAWUC) executive officer Doug Hall said there were many water policy issues that rural real estate agents needed to be aware of, but these were often neglected because of their complexity.

He said WAWUC was formed in 1998 to protect and promote the rights of water users, especially those relying on springfed dams, runoff and unlicensed surface water, in the face of evolving State water legislation.

The members of the apolitical WAWUC body are individual businesses and nine industry peak bodies, including those advocating for farmers.

Mr Hall said some of the key guiding principles of the organisation were private property rights, rule of law, self-interest, self-reliance, free markets and competition.

He has a long history of advocacy, having had input to many water policies through submissions and public meetings.

Mr Hall said in recent years, there had been a range of legislation and frameworks that intersected with water rights in Western Australia and nationally.

He said these included binding and non-binding international agreements with the Federal government, national agreements and legislation, State legislation and local government powers.

"These cover water, native title and heritage protection, among other issues," Mr Hall said.

"Local government can also significantly influence private property rights in water through planning, regulations and infrastructure positions.

"Some examples are climate adaptation strategies, local biodiversity strategies and reconciliation strategies.

"The Aboriginal Heritage Protection Act is particularly significant for water implications."

Mr Hall said the future should involve local ownership and management of water resources, with minimal threats to private property rights in water.

He said such threats to private property rights in water included the complexity of organisations, complacency, new environmental and Indigenous stakeholder interests, government regulations and bureaucracy, co-design rights, lack of government consultation and an emergence of a fourth tier of governance - Indigenous organisations.

"These factors may lead to inefficient and restrictive regulatory processes," Mr Hall said.

"It is a good idea for real estate agents to include all interested parties in water issues at the start of property negotiations.

"Stop being complacent about water and stop taking water for granted.

"Water is the most fundamental resource and it is best if advocacy groups collaborate and co-ordinate their efforts."

title: Canberra needs a climate plan: chair
bodyText:
'These things may not happen and yet we need to build for the possibility of risks.'

Canberra should prepare for days with temperatures soaring to 55 degrees and seize opportunities to invest in climate action that improves the health of the capital's residents, the new chair of the ACT Climate Change Council says.

Arnagretta Hunter, a cardiologist, said she thought the city needed to plan for temperature ranges from minus 15 to 55 degrees.

"These are built environment challenges we've not seen before, and this really asks us to think about where we work, how we work, how we look after each other, and the way in which we allocate our resources," Dr Hunter told budget estimates on Friday.

"It's a challenge around evaluation as well, because these things may not happen, and yet we need to build for the possibility of risks which we don't understand because we haven't seen them in the past.

"It's a complex area, but it's also one of the tremendous opportunities."

Dr Hunter said there needed to be an explicit acknowledgement of the need for imagination in climate adaptation work, to begin to "think about the sorts of things that haven't happened before and that might happen".

Dr Hunter, who served on the Climate Change Council since 2022 and was made chair last month, said investments in climate change mitigation could be readily justified on the grounds that those efforts actually protected and preserved human health.

"In a domestic home environment, particularly for those with less economic privilege, where we've got the opportunity to take gas out of the home environment for people who can't otherwise afford it, we actually can improve their health and wellbeing," she said.

"Isn't that a remarkable win-win?"

Meanwhile, the ACT Greens said work on climate change and environmental protection has "ground to a halt" since their members left cabinet after the October 2024 election and criticised the government for not lifting funding for environment groups.

Climate Change and Environment Minister Suzanne Orr, on Friday, was unable to say before the budget estimates committee precisely when a new territory climate change strategy would be completed.

The minister said the new strategy was being developed through cabinet processes with a plan to begin public consultation by year's end.

title: FED:More 'infrastructure, not advisers' key to Pacific aid
bodyText:
Spending more aid dollars on infrastructure in the Pacific and less on advisors would help Australia better compete with China for influence in the region, a think tank says.
   A "modest" reduction in advisers could fund almost half a billion dollars per year in desperately needed regional climate change adaptation investment, independent international policy think tank The Lowy Institute says.


   "Australia should be spending a lot more of its foreign aid to the Pacific on hard infrastructure investments related to helping the region become much more resilient to climate change," the institute's Indo-Pacific Development Centre director Roland Rajah told AAP.
   Pacific Island countries are among the most climate-vulnerable in the world and need to improve their physical infrastructure to cope with changing weather patterns and their impacts.
   This includes coastal protection projects to prevent flooding in urban centres and increasing the durability and resilience of general infrastructure, such as roads and drainage systems.
   Ports also need bolstering to cope with rising sea levels, and public buildings need to be more resilient to cyclones. Maintenance costs are also expected to rise with increased wear and tear.
   Australia spends about $2 billion per year in the Pacific and has signed deals for $2 billion in infrastructure funding.
   However, it only translates to about $80 million being spent on infrastructure projects each year, Mr Rajah said - well below the $2.3 billion the International Monetary Fund estimates the Pacific Island nations need to spend annually on climate adaptation.
   Australia's infrastructure investment facility for the Pacific is also almost out of funds.
   "If we just do what we've done and stop, then that's not really going to be very much," Mr Rajah said.
   "There needs to be some kind of top-up, and the obvious solution would just be to have a bigger aid program, but the politics around that just don't seem that favourable."
   The solution could be to cut the amount Australia spends on technical advice for Pacific Island nations to promote economic and governance reform, which is estimated to be about $700 million annually.
   "It's a very worthy goal, but ... that's a bit overkill, and we could usefully be repositioning that towards spending more on climate infrastructure," Mr Rajah said.
   More visible and tangible support for the Pacific's most pressing concern would also help Australia better compete with China for geo-strategic influence in the region.
   "We're completely outspending China in terms of foreign aid ... China's giving a few hundred million dollars a year, but we don't get much bang for our buck," Mr Rajah said.
   "Part of the reason is that China does much more tangible things like infrastructure, and we focus on these other things like governance.
   "Making the shift is smart development and smart diplomacy."

title: July 31, 2025: University of Technology Sydney: Research hub goes with the grain for AI adoption
bodyText:
A new $11.7 million research hub will explore how the Australian grain industry can better use responsible artificial intelligence to be more productive and sustainable.

The Australian Research Council (ARC) Industrial Transformation Research Hub in Responsible AI for a Sustainable Grain Industry will develop cutting-edge artificial intelligence (AI) technologies to reduce fertiliser and diesel use, lower carbon emissions, and improve climate adaptation.

Led by Distinguished Professor Jie Lu, the research hub is a collaboration between experts from three Australian universities (UTS, University of Adelaide, Murdoch University), state government agencies, and 10 companies and industry organisations.

The hub has received $5 million from the ARC over the next five years, on top of $6.7 million from partner organisations.

"Australia has been at the forefront in using AI-driven new technology to drive the productivity and sustainability of agricultural industries including grains," said the new ARC research hub's director, Distinguished Professor Jie Lu.

"From sowing to distribution, AI is already providing insights and solutions for smarter and more sustainable grain-growing practices. However, further adoption of the technology will rely on developing responsible AI tools that are trusted by grain growers to be explainable and safe."

A groundbreaking study has found that women who experienced physical abuse in the context of domestic violence are more likely to suffer from long-term mental health challenges, even decades after the abuse has ended.

Approximately 30% of women worldwide will experience intimate partner violence - commonly referred to as domestic violence - in their lifetime. Often this will involve physical abuse, including risk of traumatic brain injury. Nevertheless, despite the prevalence of domestic violence and associated brain injuries, there has been little research into its potential long-lasting effects on brain health.

Image of a brain scan

To address this, The Drake IPV Study, led by the Professor Willie Stewart, Honorary Professor at the University of Glasgow, explored the mental health consequences associated with domestic violence and traumatic brain injury. The results are published in BMJ Mental Health.

Working with data from the multi-centre PREVENT Dementia Study, the researchers found that 14% of 632 study participants, who were aged 40-59 years-old at recruitment, reported a history of domestic violence with physical abuse. Compared with unexposed participants, a history of domestic violence was associated with higher traumatic brain injury exposure, alongside higher lifetime and ongoing diagnoses of mental health disorders, such as depression, anxiety, sleep disorders and PTSD.

Notably, the risk of ongoing mid-life mental health disorders remained despite the exposure to domestic violence having ceased, on average, 27 years before assessment.

Most local, human-induced causes show measurable impacts within years and the framework provides a clear basis for prioritising timely, locally grounded action with a deeper understanding of the systems that shape these complex and dynamic environments.

Publishing their findings today in Nature Climate Change, the team includes scientists from the Universities of East Anglia, Southampton and Oxford in the UK, and Deltares, TU Delft, Wageningen University and Utrecht University in The Netherlands.

title: August 19, 2025: Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation Launches $1M A.I. Competition for Alzheimer's Breakthroughs
bodyText:
The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is spearheading a new initiative aimed at accelerating research into Alzheimer's disease, a condition currently affecting more than 7 million Americans. On 19th August 2025, the foundation, in collaboration with the Alzheimer's Disease Data Initiative (AD Data Initiative), announced an A.I. competition offering a $1 million prize for innovative solutions targeting Alzheimer's and related forms of dementia.

The Alzheimer's Insights A.I. Prize is designed to galvanize the global innovation community to address the urgent need for advancements in dementia research. Niranjan Bose, the interim executive director of the AD Data Initiative, emphasized the transformative potential of A.I. in his statement, noting that the technology could significantly enhance the speed and scale of research efforts. "A.I. has the potential to revolutionize the pace and scale of dementia research-providing an opportunity we cannot afford to miss out on, especially with so many lives at risk," said Bose.

Bill Gates, who has been an advocate for Alzheimer's research since the founding of the AD Data Initiative in 2020, has a personal connection to the cause, having lost his father to the disease. "We are closer than ever before to a world where no one has to watch someone they love suffer from this awful disease," Gates remarked in a recent Father's Day post. The competition aims to attract A.I. and machine learning engineers, computational biomedicine experts, and clinical specialists, thereby broadening the scope of collaboration in the field.

Alzheimer's disease presents unique challenges due to its complex nature, with multiple causes and biological pathways that complicate research efforts. The AD Data Initiative believes that agentic A.I. can autonomously analyze vast datasets, uncovering insights that human researchers might overlook. Gregory Moore, a senior advisor at both Gates Ventures and the AD Data Initiative, highlighted the shift that A.I. could bring to Alzheimer's research, moving from reactive to predictive methodologies. This includes identifying novel biomarkers, optimizing clinical trial designs, and revealing new opportunities for drug development.

Over the years, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has invested billions into public health initiatives. Gates' personal contributions to Alzheimer's research have included substantial donations aimed at supporting novel treatments and improving diagnostics. With the launch of this new A.I. competition, the foundation seeks to catalyze further innovation and progress in the fight against Alzheimer's disease. Semi-finalists are expected to be announced in December, with finalists competing in March at the Alzheimer's Disease and Parkinson's Disease Conference in Copenhagen.

title: Fire lab a 'game-changer'
bodyText:
A UTAS bushfire laboratory which promises to put Tasmania at the epicentre of global research into plant flammability and smoke emissions has been described as a "game-changer" for public health.

Launching in Hobart on Thursday, FireLab3 has been lauded as an internationally significant initiative allowing researchers to precisely measure combustion-generated pollution levels, and environmental impacts linked to air quality.

Professor David Bowman said the new facility, which will harness the combined knowledge of the Menzies Institute for Medical Research and the UTAS Fire Centre Research Hub, would help tackle the complex and pressing challenges associated with climate change.

"This is not just a Tasmanian asset - it's a global resource," Professor Bowman, ARC Laureate Fellow and Director of the Fire Centre, said.

"With FireLab3, we can now generate world-class data to inform policies and interventions for bushfire preparedness and resilience that protect people, ecosystems and infrastructure in a warming world." The new facility consists of three separate laboratories, including the Flammability Lab, which will help researchers compare how different plants burn in both wet and dry conditions, and to investigate the impacts of smoke taint on crops such as wine grapes.

The John Todd Bioenergy Laboratory will research methods to reduce toxic wood-heater emissions, while the Venn Exposure Lab's climate hut is a highly specialised controlled-exposure chamber that simulates real-world atmospheric conditions.

UTAS public health physician and environmental epidemiologist Professor Fay Johnston said the FireLab would allow the university's environmental health research group to provide their work with greater detail than ever before.

"We are entering a new era where the impacts of fire and air quality on human health can be measured and understood with far greater precision," Professor Johnston said.

"FireLab3 gives us the ability to design more effective interventions to protect communities from bushfire smoke, extreme heat and wood heater emissions. It's a game-changer for public health and climate adaptation." The only facility of its kind in the southern hemisphere, the establishment of FireLab3 further cemented Tasmania's growing reputation as a leader in sustainability, climate research, and evidence-based action on environmental health, Professor Johnston said. duncan.abey@news.com.au

+ UC RESEARCH AIMS TO SHED LIGHT ON DARK SKIES

Ever noticed how few stars you'll see when you're visiting a big city? That's the result of light pollution that stems from tightly clustered streetlights, buildings, homes and other urban infrastructure, not to mention an increasing number of satellites. It's a growing issue that not only dims our view of the cosmos but also limits our connection to stories and traditions written in the stars.

As recipient of the Borrin Foundation's 2025 Travel and Learning Award, Dr Shea Esterling of Te Whare Wananga o Waitaha | University of Canterbury's Te Kaupeka Tura | Faculty of Law will be exploring International Dark Sky Places (IDSP) across Aotearoa New Zealand and Australia this year.

DarkSky International defines IDSPs as certified global locations with naturally dark skies and minimal light pollution, ideal for stargazing. Takapo, home to UC's Mount John Observatory, a world-renowned astronomical research centre, is one of nine officially recognised IDSPs in Aotearoa New Zealand.

The research funding awarded will enable Dr Esterling to investigate how IDSPs are regulated and how best to protect them, not just for astronomy, but as vital components of our shared cultural heritage.

Her study will explore how law and policy can help preserve dark skies, particularly in a time when space activity is accelerating but legislation hasn't quite caught up.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CANTERBURY: EARLY LITERACY SUPPORT CRITICAL FOR KIDS NEEDING EXTRA HELP

When 'Lola' started primary school, she had limited oral language, was highly anxious and would read by copying others in the group, not even really looking at or following the text on the page.

After a term, she was still unsure of her letter sounds and how to blend sounds together to make words - the very early and necessary skills for literacy.

One year later, Lola loves reading and writing. She often chooses to independently write letters and cards to friends. Her family says that everywhere they go, she attempts reading the signs she sees.

'Lola' is among thousands of young Kiwi kids benefitting from early help after struggling with reading and spelling, according to new findings from one of the largest controlled studies of the impact of literacy intervention.

Researchers Professors Brigid McNeill and Gail Gillon from Te Whare Wananga o Waitaha | University of Canterbury (UC) studied early literacy development in 3,700 five- and six-year-olds to see if providing more intensive, smaller reading groups is making a difference.

Source: Company Website

+ SUSTAINABLE SPACE GROWTH POSSIBLE, UC RESEARCH SHOWS

With the space industry rapidly gaining momentum, new research from Te Whare Wananga o Waitaha | University of Canterbury (UC) highlights the importance of managing this growth sustainably to protect our planet's wellbeing.

UC supports the advancement of aerospace through research, partnerships, and talent development - and recognises the importance of doing so in ways that protect future generations. This research adds to a growing body of knowledge guiding the sector's sustainable development.

The ozone layer protects life on Earth from harmful solar ultraviolet (UV) rays and a hole discovered in the 1980s, caused by human-originated pollutants, is slowly healing thanks to global action generated by the Montreal Protocol. But emissions from rocket launches, particularly certain chemicals and particulates, could pose a new challenge.

The UC-led study, published in npj Climate and Atmospheric Science, modelled atmospheric impacts from projected rocket launch rates. While 2019 saw 102 launches, by 2024 that increased to 258 worldwide, with that number expected to be exceeded in 2025. At multiple sites worldwide, the launch industry expects expansive future growth.

The findings show that with around 2,000 launches per year - nearly ten times current levels - the ozone layer could thin by up to 3%, with the most significant losses over Antarctica.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CANTERBURY: DRIVE TO SUCCEED

With the UCMotorsport team regularly making headlines for their global success and innovation, Te Whare Wananga o Waitaha | University of Canterbury (UC) Engineering students are no strangers to the world of fast cars and innovation.

Founded by David Dicker in 2016, Rodin Cars is another Canterbury Motorsport venture making waves in this globally lucrative industry. A lifelong enthusiast with a deep passion for high-performance engineering, Dicker's vision is to build a vehicle that can outperform current Formula One cars.

But Rodin's pursuit of excellence extends beyond building exceptional cars. Rodin is committed to supporting others to perform at their best, whether in motorsport, education, or community engagement.

To demonstrate his commitment to nurturing that level of excellence, Dicker is sponsoring two new UC Engineering scholarship for undergraduate students.

The scholarship will ensure those with a passion for the industry are supported, regardless of their background. "New Zealand's got the talent. We just need to back the ones who are willing to work for it. We are proud to invest in the next generation of engineers and look forward to their impact on the industry," says David.

As the founder and former CEO of Dicker Data, David had some straightforward advice for students "If you don't understand something, ask. Find someone who knows. But to grow you've got to love the work. Whether you're on a racetrack or in a garage, you've got to want to be there."

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CANTERBURY: PACIFIC AND INDIGENOUS VOICES LEAD WORLDS LARGEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION EVENT

The event is being held at Te Pae Christchurch Convention Centre and throughout Otautahi Christchurch (13-16 October). Adaptation Futures is the world's largest and most important climate adaptation event bringing together scientists, governments and industry.

More than 200 in-person and online sessions will cover AF2025's core themes of Indigenous innovation and leadership; oceans, islands, and futures; cities, settlements and infrastructure; the food, water, and biodiversity nexus; health, wellbeing, and future generations; the art of adaptation, communication and education; and beyond adaptation. This year's event will have a particular emphasis on issues for the Pacific and Indigenous people.

New Zealand Minister of Climate Change Simon Watts said the country is working on a national adaptation framework to better understand and manage the risks of a changing climate, and hosting AF2025 would boost these conversations.

"I am looking forward to welcoming international delegates to Adaptation Futures in Christchurch in October. Bringing together world experts on adaptation strengthens the discussions we're already having here in New Zealand on how to face some of climate change's biggest challenges," he said.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CANTERBURY: ARTIST IN RESIDENCE OPPORTUNITY OFFERED DURING WORLDS LARGEST CLIMATE ADAPTATION EVENT

The three-month residency, funded by Creative New Zealand, includes an exciting chance to take part in a public exhibition that will be part of the world's largest international climate change adaptation event - Adaptation Futures 2025 (AF2025).

AF2025 co-convenor Distinguished Professor Steven Ratuva of the University of Canterbury said proposals are invited from Pacific artists whose work addresses climate change issues, such as the core themes for AF2025.

"This three-month residency is a fantastic opportunity for Pacific artists to enhance their existing practice, develop an innovative art project of significance, and contribute to the enrichment of Pacific art culture. They can also engage with other Pacific artists at the newly established Pacific Creative Hub at UC," he said.

Adaptation Futures will be held in Otautahi Christchurch at Te Pae Christchurch Convention Centre on 13-16 October. It is the flagship event of the United Nations World Adaptation Science Programme (WASP). It enables leading practitioners, policy makers, researchers, thought leaders and academics from across the globe to gather to collaborate and inspire urgent efforts to accelerate adaptation for a more resilient climate and fairer future.

This year's event, which has a particular focus on Indigenous and Pacific innovation and leadership in response to climate change, is co-hosted by WASP and UC. It is supported by New Zealand government agencies, national and international research organisations and businesses, and foundation sponsor The Adaptation Fund.

"The urgent need to scale up our global efforts to protect vulnerable communities, businesses, and environments from the impact of climate change, including Pacific Islands, is more pressing than ever," AF2025 co-convenor Professor Bronwyn Hayward of the University of Canterbury said.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CANTERBURY: HARNESSING VIRUSES TO PROTECT BEES, SALMON AND ONE DAY, HUMANS

Microbiologist Associate Professor Heather Hendrickson is leading ground-breaking research into bacteriophages-natural viruses that infect and destroy bacteria. Based at Te Whare Wananga o Waitaha | University of Canterbury (UC), her work focuses on protecting honeybees and farmed salmon from serious bacterial diseases without relying on antibiotics or chemicals.

"About 80% of antibiotics globally are used in primary industries," says Associate Professor Hendrickson. "We want to pivot away from that kind of use and replace it with natural biocontrols like phages - and perhaps one day even explore their medical use."

The research, funded through an MBIE Endeavour programme, also involves Professor Peter Fineran from the University of Otago, who is applying phage science to combat plant diseases affecting fruit, including cherries.

Phages are highly specific, targeting only harmful bacteria and leaving beneficial microbes intact. By combining different phages in 'cocktails,' researchers can also reduce the chance of bacterial resistance.

"You can think of phages like a shield or armour you apply in advance of being exposed to pathogens," Associate Professor Hendrickson says. "While we've only discovered maybe 30 or 40 classes of antibiotics there are a trillion bacteriophages for every grain of sand on the planet, and ten times more phages than bacteria. They are an untapped natural resource already in the soil, water, and even on our skin - they're all around us."

Source: Company Website

title: AgScenarios2050 report offers a glimpse into the future of agriculture
bodyText:
"Foresighting helps us stretch our thinking," Dr Rose Roche said.

If the 25 years between 2000 and now is anything to go by, the year 2050 could potentially be unrecognisable.

At the Grower Group Alliance (GGA) Forum25 in Perth last week, four possible futures of agriculture in 2050 were outlined by CSIRO digital innovations lead, Dr Rose Roche.

The Ag2050 Scenarios report, conducted by CSIRO is an evidence-based literature review delving into how the regions could look based on its ability to handle current and emerging global challenges.

"It's not about predicting a single future, but it's about equipping ourselves to make better choices in the face of uncertainty," Dr Roche said.

The report was produced with hundreds of hours of consultation, workshops and modelling in a broad literature review.

"Often when we predict a future outcome, like rainfall or crop yields, we're working with a really narrow band of possibilities, we're thinking about past experiences and applying that to the future," Dr Roche said.

"While that can offer precision, it doesn't really allow us to think about or capture the range of possibilities surrounding our future.

"Foresighting helps us take that worldview and stretch our thinking.

"Instead of asking what is most likely or most probable, we can think about what could plausibly happen, and then what would we prefer to strive for?

According to the report, 14 key drivers of change were identified, categorised under five broad categories: global context, environment and climate, land and water, innovation and productivity, and trade and market access.

Two outcomes for Australian agriculture are possible if the system can achieve its full potential.

Scenario one describes regional agricultural capitals, where technology increases productivity through intensified systems, decreasing emissions, a skilled and diverse workforce, and evidence-based and trade-led frameworks.

Scenario two, named land stewardship, also showed increasing productivity and resilience, diversified and innovative market opportunities, decreased emissions, improved biodiversity, a strong and skilled workforce which is attracted to working in the sector, and strong Australian branding for high-value products.

However, with only incremental progression to innovation and climate adaptation, the sector plateaus.

This is described in scenario three - climate survival.

In this scenario, productivity and efficiency reach a ceiling and plateau, biodiversity and ecology slowly deteriorate, problems with workforce attraction and retention arise, and export markets are maintained.

The fourth and final scenario, system decline, describes a failure to address growing challenges.

It outlines a decline in yields and productivity, food and fibre production using traditional systems is intensified, biodiversity and ecology decline, workforce shrinkage, and exports to low-price markets.

For each of these scenarios, Dr Roche created a profile of the kind of person working in each environment.

"(The profiles) aren't real, but they reflect real data, real places and real possibilities," she said.

"Their stories are drawn from dozens of expert workshops and shared deliberation."

"It's clear that siloed thinking isn't enough, and whilst we have many pressing issues to deal with today, we also need to keep an eye on the long view.

"That means creating collaborative spaces, applying system thinking and including the voices strongly in those historically underrepresented, so Indigenous landholders, young people and regional communities, so everyone has a voice in what they need for the future."

title: July 31, 2025: University of Technology Sydney: Hot air and hard truths
bodyText:
The Information Policy and Integrity Exchange (IPIE) has released a landmark review on climate misinformation and disinformation, synthesising a decade of research across 300 studies. The review reveals a troubling evolution in climate disinformation tactics. Denialism is giving way to more insidious strategies - such as sowing doubt about renewable energy, exaggerating scientific uncertainty, and reframing climate action as elitist overreach. These tactics are increasingly networked and algorithmically amplified, muddying public understanding and delaying urgent policy responses.

Our analysis identifies five dominant narrative frames used to distort climate science: denial of anthropogenic causes; distraction through unrelated crises; attacks on climate advocates; promotion of false solutions; and strategic amplification of uncertainty. These frames are not random - they are often deployed by powerful actors with vested interests in fossil fuel economies and political polarisation.

The United Nations has declared that access to information about climate change is a human right. They've even outlined a set of global principles for maintaining the integrity of publicly available information about climate change. Our study shows that misleading information is adding to the climate crisis.

Take, for example, the way in which critics swiftly blamed solar and wind energy for the massive blackout in Spain and Portugal on April 28. This was amplified on social media for weeks before the Spanish government finally declared that the national grid operator and private power generation firms were responsible due to the power grid's lack of capacity to control grid voltage. According to one of the lead authors of the report, Professor Klaus Jensen, mis and disinformation erodes public trust and impairs collective decision-making. It not only obstructs emissions reduction efforts but also delays climate adaptation.

title: Councils call for help with $2bn disaster bill
bodyText:
Councils are expected to spend $2bn over the next five years in managing the impacts of floods, fires and other natural disasters, with the peak body for local governments calling on the commonwealth to contribute more.

As 1300 mayors, shire presidents and councillors descended on Canberra this week for a major summit held by the Australian Local Government Association, fresh research shows the billions of dollars being spent by councils on preparing for and recovering from disaster events.

Speaking at the NGA in Canberra, ALGA president Matt Burnett said the changing climate was "putting pressure on communities, and this groundbreaking research shows councils are leading the way in preparing for and managing these ever-increasing impacts, including from natural disasters".

"Climate-resilient infrastructure is expensive and takes time to build, so we need sustainable funding from the federal government," Mr Burnett said.

According to the findings in ALGA's report, local governments' expenditure on climate adaptation is on track to reach up to $400m a year, or $2bn by 2030. Concern over the federal government not meeting needs that councils see as well within commonwealth responsibility has been long-standing. But Assistant Minister for Climate Change and Energy and Assistant Minister for Emergency Management Josh Wilson said the government had made a range of investments that would help local governments in managing and preparing for natural disasters.

title: $62m funding lift for project hubs, training centres
bodyText:
Rocket boosters, robotic farming and AI-driven medical implants are among 13 projects sharing $62m in taxpayer funding for new research hubs and training centres.

The Australian Research Council on Tuesday announced the hubs, which require university researchers to collaborate with industry, via its Industrial Transformation Training Centres.

ARC chief executive Professor Ute Roessner said the new hubs and training centres will drive innovative research to advance Australian industry and research capability.

The University of Queensland will lead a research hub for mass manufacturing of high-temperature composites, to be used for building high-speed "flight vehicles" and rocket boosters.

Researchers will team up with government and private companies including the Defence Science and Technology Group, as well as Lockheed Martin Australia and Quickstep Technologies.

At Monash University, a new research hub in cyber-farming for sustainable and resilient agriculture will pioneer robotic and data-driven technologies aimed at producing more sustainable and resilient crops.

Liancheng USA, USL Robotics and Fankhauser Apples are among the companies collaborating with the academics.

The University of NSW will host a research hub for next-generation mining methods, with a target to sustainably meet a 40-fold increase in demand for critical minerals.

BHP, the International Copper Association and Accenture Australia are among the private industry collaborators.

At RMIT University, a research hub for intelligent contaminant-sensing in complex environments will integrate miniaturised sensors with artificial intelligence to provide real-time assessment of chemical or biological contaminants in air, water and soil. The industry partners include the South East Water Corporation, Surenut Pty Ltd, Brightspace AI and the Melbourne Water Corporation.

Monash University will host a research hub for critical energy separation materials, aimed at lowering the cost of transporting energy, in collaboration with companies including Electralith, Epe Innovation and EnvirostreamAustralia.

The University of Technology Sydney has won funding for a research hub in responsible AI for a sustainable grain industry, with the aim of reducing fertiliser and diesel use, and improving climate adaptation.

Academics will partner with industry experts from groups including the Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development, Grain Producers SA and the Western Australian Agriculture Authority.

The six new industrial research hubs will share in $27.3m of funding, with another $34.7m shared between seven new industrial transformation training centres.

Group of Eight chief executive Vicki Thomson, representing the research-intensive universities, said investment in research and development has fallen to 1.7 per cent of GDP, well below the OECD average of 2.7 per cent.

She called on the Albanese government to lift R&D spending to 3 per cent of GDP to boost national productivity.

"Australia is home to some of the world's smartest and most innovative minds," she said. "We punch well above our weight.

"Historically, investment in national research and innovation has given us advancements such as wi-fi, cancer therapies, cochlear implants, electric vehicles, quantum computing and more. "It is how we grow our self-sufficiency and stay globally competitive â€¦ all we need is a kickstart."

Sophisticated computer modelling of the Clyde by researchers at the University of Glasgow suggests that urban planners will need to adopt a 'right size, right place' approach to tidal flood management in the years to come.

A groundbreaking study has found that women who experienced physical abuse in the context of domestic violence are more likely to suffer from long-term mental health challenges, even decades after the abuse has ended.

Approximately 30% of women worldwide will experience intimate partner violence - commonly referred to as domestic violence - in their lifetime. Often this will involve physical abuse, including risk of traumatic brain injury. Researchers, local government and food organisations are coming together to tackle poor diet and ill health in some of the most deprived areas in Glasgow.

The new research project, funded with more than £1m by UK Research & Innovation, aims to better understand the reasons for dietary and health inequalities in low-income areas of Glasgow. The project will also evaluate the impact of the establishment of new, locally run food markets to help support healthful diets through better access to healthier produce.

The three-year partnership is led by Dr Ada Garcia at the University of Glasgow, and includes experts from The Glasgow School of Art and the Glasgow Centre for Population Health, alongside a wider team including Glasgow City Council, Glasgow Food Policy Partnership and Glasgow Community Food Network.

title: June 17, 2025: SWANSEA UNIVERSITY LEADS CONSORTIUM AWARDED Pound3M FOR NATIONAL PROJECT USING NATURE TO HELP CITIES TACKLE CLIMATE CHANGE
bodyText:
Swansea University has been awarded Pound3m by the Arts and Humanities Research Council (AHRC) to lead a major new project that will explore how nature can help cities adapt to climate change.

The four-year project is one of just three across the UK chosen for funding through AHRC's new Mission Awards. It takes a fresh, collaborative approach to research, developed with input from societal partners and experts from a wide range of fields.

Called 'Retrofitting for the Future: Nature-Based Solutions for Climate Adaptation', the project will look at how cities and their citizens can become healthier, greener, and more resilient by building stronger connections with nature. This includes rethinking how we design and reuse buildings and public spaces - bringing in natural elements like plants, water, and daylight to improve wellbeing and support the environment.

title: Mark Suzman's Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation Launches $1M A.I. Competition for Alzheimer's Breakthroughs August 20, 2025
bodyText:
The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is spearheading a new initiative aimed at accelerating research into Alzheimer's disease, a condition currently affecting more than 7 million Americans. On 19th August 2025, the foundation, in collaboration with the Alzheimer's Disease Data Initiative (AD Data Initiative), announced an A.I. competition offering a $1 million prize for innovative solutions targeting Alzheimer's and related forms of dementia.

The Alzheimer's Insights A.I. Prize is designed to galvanize the global innovation community to address the urgent need for advancements in dementia research. Niranjan Bose, the interim executive director of the AD Data Initiative, emphasized the transformative potential of A.I. in his statement, noting that the technology could significantly enhance the speed and scale of research efforts. "A.I. has the potential to revolutionize the pace and scale of dementia research-providing an opportunity we cannot afford to miss out on, especially with so many lives at risk," said Bose.

Bill Gates, who has been an advocate for Alzheimer's research since the founding of the AD Data Initiative in 2020, has a personal connection to the cause, having lost his father to the disease. "We are closer than ever before to a world where no one has to watch someone they love suffer from this awful disease," Gates remarked in a recent Father's Day post. The competition aims to attract A.I. and machine learning engineers, computational biomedicine experts, and clinical specialists, thereby broadening the scope of collaboration in the field.

Alzheimer's disease presents unique challenges due to its complex nature, with multiple causes and biological pathways that complicate research efforts. The AD Data Initiative believes that agentic A.I. can autonomously analyze vast datasets, uncovering insights that human researchers might overlook. Gregory Moore, a senior advisor at both Gates Ventures and the AD Data Initiative, highlighted the shift that A.I. could bring to Alzheimer's research, moving from reactive to predictive methodologies. This includes identifying novel biomarkers, optimizing clinical trial designs, and revealing new opportunities for drug development.

Over the years, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has invested billions into public health initiatives. Gates' personal contributions to Alzheimer's research have included substantial donations aimed at supporting novel treatments and improving diagnostics. With the launch of this new A.I. competition, the foundation seeks to catalyze further innovation and progress in the fight against Alzheimer's disease. Semi-finalists are expected to be announced in December, with finalists competing in March at the Alzheimer's Disease and Parkinson's Disease Conference in Copenhagen.

SECTION 1 BIOGRAPHY: MARK SUZMAN CEO & Director

As CEO of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, Mark Suzman leads the organization in service of our mission - to help every person have the opportunity to live a healthy, productive life. Knowing that we cannot achieve that mission alone, he brings a deep commitment to building partnerships and ensuring that the culture of the foundation directly enables the impact we aspire to have. Mark serves as a member of the foundation's board of trustees in his role as CEO.

Mark's upbringing in apartheid South Africa instilled in him a desire to use the advantages afforded to him to help tackle injustice and inequality. He began his career doing that through journalism, writing for the Johannesburg Star and then the Financial Times, where he covered international trade policy, welfare reform, and political issues, including the historic 1994 election of Nelson Mandela. In 2000, Mark joined the United Nations, where he was part of the effort to implement the Millennium Development Goals under the leadership of then Secretary-General Kofi Annan. He held multiple positions at the UN over his six-year tenure, including senior advisor for policy and strategic communications in the Office of the Secretary General, and policy director in the Office of the Administrator of the United Nations Development Program.

Mark joined the foundation in 2007 as director of Global Development Policy, Advocacy, and Special Initiatives. Prior to becoming CEO, he served as managing director of Country Offices, president of Global Policy and Advocacy, and chief strategy officer. In these roles, he built and oversaw the development of the foundation's offices in India, China, Africa, and Europe, and managed the foundation's relationships with government, private philanthropists, and civil society. He also implemented a new system for how the foundation measures impact and manages tradeoffs across its strategic priorities.

Mark holds a doctorate in international relations from Oxford University, where he was a Rhodes Scholar. He earned his bachelor's degree, summa cum laude, from Harvard University.

The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, founded in 2000 by Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates, is a global philanthropic organization headquartered in Seattle, Washington. With over 1,700 employees, it manages an endowment of $67 billion, focusing on global health, education, and poverty alleviation. In 2024, it invested $8.6 billion in grants, targeting diseases like malaria and polio. Its culture emphasizes data-driven impact, collaboration, and diversity, with extensive staff training. Renamed in 2024 after Melindas resignation, Bill Gates remains sole chair. Competing with other foundations like Wellcome Trust, it stands out for its scale and transparency, offering public access to spending data. title: FED:Australia may be target of legal action on climate
bodyText:
Australia could become the subject of legal action after an international court said countries have an obligation to prevent climate change harm and redress damage caused by greenhouse gas emissions.
   The non-binding advisory opinion was issued by a 15-judge panel at the International Court of Justice in The Hague in The Netherlands overnight.


   It opens the way for countries to potentially sue each other over climate change impacts.
   Social justice group ActionAidAustralia, which lobbies for women's rights, said the advice was a wake-up call for the Labor federal government.
   "This ruling is a powerful tool we can use to demand that those most responsible for this climate crisis be held accountable," the group's Vanuatu country manager Flora Vano said on Thursday.
   Ms Fino, who travelled to the Hague last year to deliver testimony as part of the court proceedings, said women and girls on the frontlines of the climate crisis will be able to fight for justice and accountability.
   ActionAidAustralia executive director Michelle Higelin said the ruling was clear.
   "Australia must do all it can to keep global heating to 1.5 degrees," she said.
   "This is not a choice, this is an obligation to take stronger and more urgent action."
   ActionAid wants the government to "urgently" transition away from fossil fuels and increase funding to low-income countries, including those in the Pacific, to support climate adaptation efforts.
   Global science and policy institute, Climate Analytics, which has an Australia-Pacific region office, said the court has pointed to potentially serious legal consequences.
   Action could be taken under customary international law if countries don't put forward climate targets aligned to the Paris Agreement to limit global warming to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels.
   "Importantly, these obligations also apply to countries whether or not they are Parties to the Paris Agreement," it added.
   Australia's current commitment to the Paris Agreement includes reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 43 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030 and achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.
   The world court's opinion comes after Vanuatu University law students argued that the people of Pacific island countries are unjustly bearing the brunt of climate change compared to high-emitting economies.
   "The degradation of the climate system and of other parts of the environment impairs the enjoyment of a range of rights protected by human rights law," presiding judge Yuji Iwasawa said, reading out the court's opinion.
   The court decision "confirms that states' obligations to protect human rights require taking measures to protect the climate system ... including mitigation and adaptation measures," judge Hilary Charlesworth, an Australian member of the court, said in a separate opinion.

title: Mark Suzman's Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation Launches $1M A.I. Competition for Alzheimer's Breakthroughs August 20, 2025
bodyText:
The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is spearheading a new initiative aimed at accelerating research into Alzheimer's disease, a condition currently affecting more than 7 million Americans. On 19th August 2025, the foundation, in collaboration with the Alzheimer's Disease Data Initiative (AD Data Initiative), announced an A.I. competition offering a $1 million prize for innovative solutions targeting Alzheimer's and related forms of dementia.

The Alzheimer's Insights A.I. Prize is designed to galvanize the global innovation community to address the urgent need for advancements in dementia research. Niranjan Bose, the interim executive director of the AD Data Initiative, emphasized the transformative potential of A.I. in his statement, noting that the technology could significantly enhance the speed and scale of research efforts. "A.I. has the potential to revolutionize the pace and scale of dementia research-providing an opportunity we cannot afford to miss out on, especially with so many lives at risk," said Bose.

Bill Gates, who has been an advocate for Alzheimer's research since the founding of the AD Data Initiative in 2020, has a personal connection to the cause, having lost his father to the disease. "We are closer than ever before to a world where no one has to watch someone they love suffer from this awful disease," Gates remarked in a recent Father's Day post. The competition aims to attract A.I. and machine learning engineers, computational biomedicine experts, and clinical specialists, thereby broadening the scope of collaboration in the field.

Alzheimer's disease presents unique challenges due to its complex nature, with multiple causes and biological pathways that complicate research efforts. The AD Data Initiative believes that agentic A.I. can autonomously analyze vast datasets, uncovering insights that human researchers might overlook. Gregory Moore, a senior advisor at both Gates Ventures and the AD Data Initiative, highlighted the shift that A.I. could bring to Alzheimer's research, moving from reactive to predictive methodologies. This includes identifying novel biomarkers, optimizing clinical trial designs, and revealing new opportunities for drug development.

Over the years, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has invested billions into public health initiatives. Gates' personal contributions to Alzheimer's research have included substantial donations aimed at supporting novel treatments and improving diagnostics. With the launch of this new A.I. competition, the foundation seeks to catalyze further innovation and progress in the fight against Alzheimer's disease. Semi-finalists are expected to be announced in December, with finalists competing in March at the Alzheimer's Disease and Parkinson's Disease Conference in Copenhagen.
